user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.2 is: Functions shall not call themselves, either directly or indirectly.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_shmem_register_generic:
```c
int metal_shmem_register_generic(struct metal_generic_shmem *shmem)
{
	/* Make sure that we can be found. */
	metal_assert(shmem->name && strlen(shmem->name) != 0);

	/* Statically registered shmem regions cannot have a destructor. */
	metal_assert(!shmem->io.ops.close);

	metal_list_add_tail(&_metal.common.generic_shmem_list,
			    &shmem->node);
	return 0;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
metal_assert(shmem->name && strlen(shmem->name) != 0);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 17.2 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation: the fragment calls metal_assert and strlen; neither function calls metal_shmem_register_generic, so there is no direct or indirect recursion. A violation would occur only if metal_assert (or strlen) were implemented such that it directly or transitively invoked metal_shmem_register_generic (i.e., if the assertion handling or any called function called back into metal_shmem_register_generic), creating recursion.
